subject: Re: [junit] Executing methods of test reflectively?
msgSnippet: Thank you. You are correct and in fact I did write my own test runner. After a little more playing (after I sent the previous email) I figured it out. My
messageBody:
Thank you. You are correct and in fact I did write my
own test runner. After a little more playing (after I
sent the previous email) I figured it out. My problem
was this... I am dynamically creating the classes with
my own custom loader. The primary reason is partly
what the junit faq/docs say about its own custom
loader use being a problem, and that is, my testcase
classes and 3rd party libraries are not on the
application classpath. Because of this, I need a way
to add various URL locations to my custom loader, such
as the compiled classes output of testcases and
locations of any 3rd party libraries the tests may
use, such as jfcUnit, httpUnit, and junit. Junit is on
our main application classpath, but the others are
not.

My harness actually runs embedded in the application
being tested (at least for the UI side), so that you
can run an individual testcase right from the UI. This
is especially helpful for developers who write unit
tests and/or GUI automation tests that want to test
their functional area as they work. Having to drop
down and run ant and try to specify a specific test to
run is a pain in the arse, especially when you have
hundreds or thousands of them over a period of time.

So because my classes are loaded dynamicaly AND the
selected method to execute is also dynamic, I was
having trouble using junit to get the result set of
the test run. I want to get something similar to the
junit output that in ant you can generate xml/html
from and see a nice web report.

The solution, as I found out was
TestSuite.createTest(Class clazz, String
methodNameToExecute);

Very nice they already had that in place. So after a
couple hours, I was able to get a TestResult back and
purposely fail some tests and see that in the test
result. I am quite the happy camper this weekend. I
thought it was going to take me a long time to get all
this working.

Originally my harness was not based on anything, not
even junit. But I figured I want the least common
denominator, JUnit in this case, so that I Can atleast
utilize existing unit tests that our developers have
already done, as well as allow for the UI automation
testcases and a little later httpUnit automation
testing as well, all runnable from the one harness in
an easy to use GUI. While tests run the harness will
update the status of each testcase (or possibly wait
until they are all done to reduce hindering test run
performance).


Thanks again.



--- Russell Gold <russgold@...> wrote:

> On Sat, 20 Nov 2004 01:09:12 -0000,
> supreme_java_guru_1
> <supreme_java_guru_1@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > Hi all,
> >
> > I am working on a GUI test harness that will run
> GUI tests, unit tests
> > and http tests. Long story short, the GUI harness
> helps in building
> > test suites. Part of this harness is allowing the
> user to add new
> > testcases in a graphical tree, define the class
> name, and the methods
> > of the class. All of this is embeddable within
> existing applications,
> > such as a Swing GUI app to allow a developer to
> quickly assemble and
> > execute individual tests without having to drop to
> the command line.
> > All of this works presently. My one BIG problem is
> trying to get the
> > test results from the test cases that are ran, so
> that I can embed
> > something similar to the <junitreport> task that
> ant has. After a
> > single test, or a group of tests run, I want my
> harness to show the
> > output.
> >
> > My initial thought was that I did not have to
> execute a junit TestCase
> > through the junit run(TestResult) method.
> Basically, I was hoping I
> > could somehow get the assertXxx() output directly.
>
>
> Essentially you are looking at writing your own test
> runner. You can
> look at numerous examples of this - look at how ant
> implements the
> junit task, look at the open source project JUnitEE
> or the
> JUnitServlet included with HttpUnit - all are
> examples of custom test
> runners which can produce their results as xml.
>
